plist.p: Good morning everybody. Welcome, thanks for joining us for our second quarter earnings report. I'm joined by David Mathers, our CFO, who will do the bulk of the presentation today, but our Divisional COOs are also with us for the Q&A session, so Rob Shafir of Asset Management, Eric Varvel of investment banking and Walter Berchtold from the private bank.

Second quarter was a difficult one, given the challenging market environment arising from persistent concerns around global economic conditions, including the European debt crisis and deteriorating economic indicators, particularly in the U.S.

Against that backdrop, our asset management and private banking divisions did well. But our investment banking results were not what we would have expected them to be, and therefore our overall result was not satisfactory. In addition, the continued strengthening of the Swiss Franc had a negative impact on our reported performance.

Let me put these results into context by making four major points. First, our business model and strategy have performed very well and put us into a position to excel over time. Despite a weak second quarter financial performance in investment banking, we earned an underlying return on equity of 10% in the second quarter, 15% for the first half of 2011 and an average return on equity of over – over the past 2.5 years, of around 17%. All of these are among best in class in the industry.

In addition, we continue to increase our client market share in every one of our businesses. For instance, in our private banking and asset management franchises, we had strong net new asset inflows of CHF14.5 billion in the second quarter. And in the investment bank, we improved our global IPO and announced M&A market shares to number two in the industry.

We have properly anticipated many of the regulatory developments, capital liquidity and compensation, and we've already adapted our business model to thrive in the face of changes to come. We believe this puts us ahead of the curve versus our peers who have many of these challenges still ahead of them.

We've already been operating under Basel 2.5 standard since the beginning of the year and have a Basel 2.5 Core tier 1 ratio of 10.2%. We are also already operating our liquidity with an NSFR of close to 100%. While this early transition makes it somewhat more challenging for us right now, the earnings and returns that we are producing will likely be stable in the future, while our peers begin to make adjustments for the new capital framework that we've already completed.

In addition, the global capital framework is evolving, as we had predicted, with a more level playing field. And finally, we have one of the cleanest and most conservatively funded balance sheets of any bank; all of this has been achieved despite fairly heavy headwinds in our business, particularly over the past year or so.

The second major point is really around those headwinds, I mean clearly, our results in the quarter demonstrate the impact of those headwinds, continued industry-wide low levels of that client activity, resulting from extreme levels of uncertainty from market and political issues around the world, had a material impact.

Low interest rates continue to prevail and the Swiss Franc continued to strengthen. We are going to do our best to clarify the impact of these factors for you, but they clearly had a negative impact on our performance in the second quarter. And perhaps most importantly, while we hope that these headwinds might dissipate, it's now clear that there's a significant risk that these conditions may persist for longer than we'd hoped. We need to ensure that we can continue to produce the highest returns in the industry, even if they do persist.

So my third point is, towards that end, we are implementing measures to reduce our cost base by CHF1 billion on a run rate basis going into 2012, over our run rate in the first half of 2011. This cost reduction alone would have increased our return on equity by two percentage points in the first half of 2011, so even if difficult conditions persist, we believe we can continue to produce best-in-class returns. These cost reductions are being made in ways that have a limited impact on the revenue line and should allow us to grow share in our businesses. The upfront cost of these reductions have been partially included in the second quarter financials, and the remainder will be included in subsequent periods.

And our fourth point is that we believe the strength of our business model and strategy, along with increased discipline on the cost side, leaves us exceptionally well-positioned to excel when these headwinds subside. More client activity, higher interest rates and the weakening of the Swiss Franc would all create substantial momentum for us and improve an already strong story.

We remain convinced of the strength of our business model; the ability to earn industry-leading returns of 15% on an operating basis in the first half of this year and 10% in the second quarter, despite tremendous headwinds against us, is a testament to the strength of the model.

The Swiss Franc movements alone depressed our pre-tax income by CHF637 million in the first half versus the same period in 2010. The ability to take decisive action to adjust the size of our business while at the same time continuing to grow our assets under management and win market share is also conformation of the strength of the franchise. Having adapted earlier to new regulatory regimes, we're better positioned to capitalize on an improvement in the market environment when it comes.

Separately, we've announced today that Walter Berchtold will move up into a role as Chairman of the Private Banking division, and Hans-Ulrich Meister will take over as the CEO of the Private Banking division effective August 1. In the Chairman's role, Walter will continue to provide support and guidance for the division, especially in the transition, and will focus an even greater amount of his time on developing our client franchise in Private Banking and more broadly, for the bank.

Walter has done an exceptional job in his period as CEO of the division. We've outgained in market share and net new assets by a factor of three to the closest competitor over the last few years. And Walter has been most closely associated with moving our private bank into what I think is the premier position among private banks.

Hans-Ulrich was brought in by Walter and I three years ago, and has done an exceptional job as CEO of Switzerland, and Walter and I believe this is the right time to make this transition, and that Hans-Ulrich is definitely the right person for it.

Hans-Ulrich will need to adapt the strategy of the private bank to his leadership style and vision, but he has been an integral part of the private banking management group over the past three years and he will continue to pursue our strategy of disciplined growth in the private bank, making sure we're tightly managed for the more challenging environment that we see today, but also poised to take strong advantage of the upside as the headwinds turn.
And with that, I'll turn it over to David.
Thank you, Brady, and good morning. I'd like to start the presentation on slide five, with an overview of the financial results.

We achieved underlying revenues of CHF6.3 billion, pre-tax income of CHF1.2 billion, and net income of CHF0.8 billion. Diluted underlying earnings per share were CHF0.53. The pre-tax income margin was 19%, and the post-tax return on equity, 10%. Total net new asset inflows were CHF14.3 billion, with a continued strong contribution from Wealth management.

Looking at the numbers for the half-year, excluding fair value and debt moves and restructuring costs, we achieved return on equity of 15% compared to 17% in the first half of 2010. Reported second quarter pre-tax income was CHF1.1 billion, and that includes CHF142 million of severance costs that were booked in the corporate center and relate to the expense reduction initiative that Brady mentioned before.
The next few slides assess the impact on our profitability from some of the market headwinds and outline how we're actually adapting to the challenging environment.

Slide six. Slide six shows how the strength of the Swiss Franc continues to adversely affect our financial performance. We estimate the Swiss Franc's strength has reduced the Group's second quarter pre-tax income by CHF348 million compared to the second quarter last year. And that means that in the first half, the strength of the Swiss Franc, because this is obviously now pre-tax income, being CHF637 million less than it would have been at the prevailing exchange rates in the first half of 2010.

Clearly compared to an average dollar, Swiss Franc exchange rate of $0.90 in the first half of '11 and $0.87 in the second quarter of '11, if the current U.S. dollar rate of $0.80 to the Swiss Franc persists the balance of the year, then we will continue to see further adverse FX impact on the Group's profitability.

We thought it would be useful to give an overall guide to this FX sensitivity. And as you can see from this, we are most sensitive to moves in the dollar, where a 10% move costs us CHF375 million up and down. Against the euro, the sensitivity for that same 10% move is CHF85 million.

Slide seven. As you are aware, low interest rates also continue to dampen our earnings. And this slide shows you our annual net interest income sensitivity by looking at changes in both short-term rates and long-term rates on our interest rate positions within the private bank and in treasury.

You can see that a higher interest rate environment benefits net interest income. For example, 100 basis point absolute move in one month LIBOR, combined with the equivalent move in the five year swap rate, would increase annualized net interest income by around CHF540 million.

I'd also point out, though, that given that current interest rates are already so low, there is only a small further impact that could come from flatter yield curves, with limited downside to net interest income from the current level.

Slide eight. In light of the pressure from the Swiss Franc's strength, the volatile macroeconomic environment and the prospect of interest rates remaining low for an extended period, we are taking decisive action to improve the profitability of the business by implementing a number of cost saving measures. We have developed plans and begun to implement the delivery of CHF1 billion of cost savings compared to the current one half '11 annualized cost run rate.

We would expect there to be limited net savings from this in 2011, but we do expect to recognize the full benefit of these savings from the beginning of 2012. These measures will result in a 4% overall reduction in head count in front office and support functions across the bank. And we will achieve the majority of the savings in investment banking. We expect these measures to have limited short-term revenue impact, as the majority of the cuts are in low return areas.

The total cost of implementation of these plans is expected to be CHF400 million to CHF450 million during 2011, and we have already recognized CHF142 million of this in our second quarter numbers. We remained committed to our growth plans and the continued focus on investments and the reallocation of resources to targeted growth businesses. For example, the ultra high net worth client segment and emerging market businesses across the private bank, investment bank and asset management, and the flow businesses within fixed income.

Slide nine. I want to be clear what we will achieve from these cost savings, and this slide is intended to put them in context. The savings will result in our 2012 cost run rate dropping by CHF1 billion from the run rate we have averaged so far in 2011. And if revenues were the same as in the first half of this year, this would have increased our post-tax ROE by approximately 2% from the 15% level that we reported already for 1H '11.

So let's turn to slide 10 for a divisional overview of the results. Given the scale of FX moves this year, we thought it would be useful to separate out the quarter-on-quarter change in revenues and expenses relating to FX moves from the underlying operational performance. So if you look at the private bank, comparing the second quarter a year ago, you can see that on FX-neutral basis, pre-tax income would have been CHF174 million higher; CHF100 million improvement in revenues, and a CHF74 million reduction in costs. But this was offset by a CHF205 million reduction from the FX impact, resulting in a lower reported income, pre-tax income, by CHF31 million.

And the bottom table shows you the same trends against the first quarter. Operating trends were positive, with improvement in recurring fees and commissions. But as a result of very low client activity, transactional revenues were significantly lower, mainly in respect to reduced brokerage and product issuing fees. Net new asset inflows remain strong.

So let's look at the Wealth management results in some more detail on slide 11. Pre-tax income for Wealth management stood at CHF595 million, and the pre-tax income margin was stable at 26% compared to the first quarter. The gross margin declined in the quarter to 115 basis points, with net new asset inflows remaining strong, CHF11.5 billion.

Now we turn to the revenue trends on slide 12. Looking at each revenue component, the underlying trends are somewhat masked by the FX movements. But in summary, after a strong first quarter of transaction-based revenues, market uncertainties and the consequent impact on client confidence resulted in subdued brokerage and product issuing volumes in the second quarter.

This was the main driver behind the fall in gross margin, which, if you exclude the CHF72 million gain on the sale of real estate, was 111 basis points in the second quarter. Client activity levels are being influenced by macroeconomic concerns, and this volatility in activity may endure for some time.
In underlying terms, pre-FX, recurring commissions and fees increased compared to the first quarter. However, due to the strong Swiss Franc, they were lower on a reported basis.

Slide 13. In our Wealth management business, we had solid net new asset inflows of CHF11.5 billion in the quarter. The annualized growth rate for the first half was 6.7%, ahead of our 6% target rate. There was a major contribution from ultra high net worth and emerging market clients, broadly distributed across our onshore and offshore booking centers.

So let's turn to corporate and institutional clients on slide 14. Pre-tax income remains strong at CHF248 million in the second quarter, with a pre-tax margin of 53%. Continued low credit provisions reflect the high quality institutional loan book and the resilient fundamentals of the Swiss economy.

So let's turn to investment banking now, slide 15. We are following here the same layout as we did on – for the private bank a few slides earlier. Revenues and profits fell substantially in investment banking due to a combination of significantly lower fixed income revenues and the appreciation of the Swiss Franc against the dollar on what are predominantly dollar-based revenues.

FX-neutral revenues were down 38% on a strong first quarter and 13% on the second quarter last year. Our performance in equities, underwriting and advisory was resilient, with revenues broadly sustained, in dollar terms, against both the first quarter of this year and the second quarter of 2010.

Slide 16. Slide 16 provides a U.S. dollar denominated P&L for investment banking, to help provide a more meaningful comparison to our U.S. peers. Although our performance was still disappointing in U.S. dollar terms, with net revenues down 38% compared to the first quarter, I would note this partly reflects a strong first quarter for Credit Suisse compared to the industry. And you will see that our half yearly revenues in dollar terms were down just 1% compared to last year, with improved dollar revenues in debt and equity underwriting advisory, broadly stable equity revenues, and fixed income sales and trading revenues down 12%.
In the second quarter, we suffered from illiquid markets driven by weak macroeconomics, which adversely affected the performance of our mortgage, credit, and rates businesses.

So if you look at fixed income on slide 17, our results were affected by the following factors: first, client risk appetite declined sharply in the quarter as a result of the weak macro environment. Second, we continue to be conservative in our overall approach to risk within the fixed income business, maintaining a low VAR stance, largely due to our concerns over direct and indirect tower (17:48) risk as a consequence of the broader market and macroeconomic issues.

And as a result, when executing client demand, we often found that executing from client positions, in certain illiquid markets, resulted in losses in our market making books in the mortgage, credit and rates businesses. Notwithstanding this, I would point out that all of our fixed income businesses did report positive revenues in the quarter.

Let's turn to slide 18, we had a resilient result from our equities business, notwithstanding muted client volumes. Although this – although these lower client volumes did result in a reduced contribution from cash equities, our prime service business delivered a record result, with higher revenues in dollar terms as client balances increased and market share improved.
And I'd also note the resilience of our equity derivatives business in the second quarter, consolidating what was a strong first quarter.

Slide 19. We delivered solid underwriting and advisory results. Equity underwriting revenues increased, reflecting market share momentum. We were ranked number two for global IPOs in the second quarter. Increased advisory revenues reflected both industry volumes and our improved number two market position in M&A. And I note that the pipeline of new activity remains healthy.

Slide 20. Pre-tax income and asset management was strong at CHF202 million, increasing both quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year. On an FX-neutral basis, the quarter-on-quarter pre-tax income improvement was 22%, with fee-based revenues increasing by 10%. Solid semi-annual performance fees and carried interest on realizations. Placement fees grew as a result of continued progress in our fundraising activities, and investment gains were strong.

Slide 21. We saw solid net new asset inflows of CHF4 billion in the second quarter, representing the eighth consecutive quarter of positive inflows into our asset management division. These were well distributed across product types, led by good contributions from our asset allocation business MACS, real estate, and commodities.

Let's turn to capital and liquidity on slide 23, please. We continue to maintain a strong capital position, with our Basel 2 Tier 1 ratio maintained at 18.2%. Our Core tier 1 ratio, which excludes hybrid capital, increased slightly to 13.1%. We've revised our projection for Basel 3 risk-weighted assets in 2013 to around CHF300 billion, compared to the original estimate that we gave last autumn of CHF340 billion. But I'd point out that's primarily driven by the strength in the Swiss Franc over the past nine months.

We have made tangible progress in mitigating the impact of Basel 3 over that period, with CHF15 billion in risk-weighted asset reductions already achieved, primarily in our exit portfolio. I'd also note that our deferred tax asset has been further reduced in the first half of the year.

The extrapolated B3 CET1 ratio at the end of 2010, assuming consensus earnings, now stands at 12.7%. However, if you fully deduct, at the beginning of 2013, all of the phase-in features between 2013 and 2019, then the ratio would be at 8.8% at the beginning of 2013.

Our funding and liquidity positions remain strong, and we're well prepared for the Basel 3 liquidity and funding requirements. Our estimate of the Basel 3 NSFR ratio, net stable funding ratio, is around 95% at the end of the first half, with the LCR also well in excess of the requirement.

Just in terms of our funding plan, we completed close to 70% of our 2011 long-term funding. And we continue to maintain a clean balance sheet, with only CHF400 million of net exposure to the Italian – to Italian sovereign risks, and immaterial exposure to Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain.

So let's just go through this a little more detail and start on slide 24. As you can see, the Basel 2 Tier 1 ratio was 18.2%. The Core tier 1 ratio increased slightly to 13.1%, and the B 2.5 Core tier 1 ratio, 10.2%. And I'd note that the regulatory capital base in all these calculations reflects a pro-rata dividend accrual of CHF1.30 per share, in line with what we paid in – respect to 2010.

On slide 25, we show the detailed calculations updating the progression risk-weighted assets under the proposed Basel 3 rule changes. If you start with the CHF204 billion risk-weighted assets under Basel 2 in 2011 on the left of the chart, we had CHF151 billion for the expected B 2.5 and B 3 changes.

The estimated mitigation benefit achievable by the end of 2012 was in the range of CHF45 billion to CHF65 billion, and this will result in B 3 post-mitigation RWA of around CHF290 billion to CHF310 billion. And the right-hand chart shows the roll-forward from our original pre-mitigation guidance. But as you can see, the major benefit is from the movement in currency rates, which reduced RWAs in Swiss Franc terms by CHF40 billion.

Just one point; in terms of RWA growth, our business plan assumes that, during the next 18 months, business growth will be achieved through the reallocation of capital between existing business lines.
Slide 26. Deferred tax asset utilization is very much on schedule. We have deferred tax assets down CHF1.6 billion, or 18% so far this year, of which approximately half is due to FX moves.

In terms of the key element of this for Basel 3, deferred tax asset on net operating losses, the reduction is CHF1 billion so far this year. And we continue to expect have minimal balances by the end of 2013.

Slide 27 is an illustrative model of how the CET1 ratio could develop, based on our capital projection from now until the end of 2013, under the Basel 3 rules and using the revised post-mitigation guidance for RWAs of approximately CHF300 billion.

The left column shows our current shareholders' equity. We have adjusted for regulatory deductions and the next 18 months of current market expectations for retained earnings, which I would remind you, do not represent forward looking statements being made by Credit Suisse management.

Just one point to note in this analysis; you can see that over the next 18 months, we are still benefited (25:30) of CHF2 billion. This reflects our policy to issue – I apologize. Shares, this reflects our policy to issue shares from conditional capital for share-based compensation awards. Once we reach the Basel 3 entry point, we may revisit this approach, which is why we've not assumed any benefit in 2013.

In terms of dilution from share awards, we expect to issue around 50 million shares between now and the end of 2012. So by the beginning of 2013, our CET1 capital gross of CHF38.2 billion to give a Basel 3 CET1 ratio of 12.7%. Market estimates for earnings in 2013 then imply a pro-forma CET1 ratio of 14.3% by the end of 2013.

Slide 28. The market has been focusing on the look-through CET1 ratio simulation when Basel 3 is implemented at the beginning of 2013. On slide 28, we assume a CET1 ratio which allows for the full deduction of phase-in allowances at the beginning of 2013, rather than allowing for the phasing in of these deductions as required under the Basel 3 and the Swiss rules.

On this much more conservative basis, our CET1 ratio would be 8.8% at the beginning of 2013. If we continue to assume CHF300 billion of risk-weighted assets, then looking out a further year would result in this ratio being 11%, well in excess of the 10% minimum that, I would remind you, is only required under the Swiss legislation currently being discussed in parliament, by 2019.

And in addition, although we've not shown it here, the cumulative CHF7.1 billion of high trigger contingent capital that will be an issue by the end of 2013, represents a further buffer of 2.4% of risk-weighted assets.

And I think, just to be clear, this look-through calculation does not represent the regulatory transition requirements by the BIS or the FINMA. It is the transitional CET1 ratio and not the look-through ratio that's the relevant trigger mechanism for the buffer capital note.

Slide 29. Finally, with the continued focus on certain Eurozone countries, we show here that we have limited exposure to both sovereign and non-sovereign counterparties in these areas. On this note, I'd like to conclude my presentation and hand back to Brady.
Thanks, David.

I think with that, we're ready to open it up to questions, and I think we'll start here in the auditorium and then we will go to any questions on phone or the webcast. If you want to raise your hand here, we will have a microphone brought over and we will try to address your questions. First question?

Philipp Zieschang from UBS. Three questions, please. The first one is, could you provide a bit of an outlook in terms of the gross margin development in Wealth management, which ranges you expect over the next couple of quarters?

The second one would be on your risk-weighted asset guidance, where you basically say you expect, in your business plan, flat risk-weighted assets until the end of 2012. And if we leave aside the current quarter, or second quarter performance in fixed income, but could you nevertheless share your thoughts in terms of the revenue growth outlook for your fixed income business, given that risk-weighted assets are flat after mitigation? And I believe your residential mortgage-backed trading business is part of your mitigation plan.

And a third one; thanks for the helpful currency impact disclosure. But if we just take the CHF205 million for the second quarter which you add to private banking, if we assume this is basically Wealth management clients, and add it to your reported profits, it means a 26% profit increase like-for-like over the second quarter 2010, where rates were low, markets have been even tough in terms of transactions. So, could you just describe a bit where this underlying improvement would have come from, because it looks like a very strong performance underlying, with 26% up? Thank you.

I think on the first question, maybe I'll quickly answer the first one and we can have maybe Walter address the third question, in terms of, as you say, the positive impacts that we've seen on the business to get us to that answer. And then I'll try to – I'll answer a little bit of the second question, but maybe Eric Varvel could add to that as well.

I think, in terms of the development on the gross margin, as you say, obviously the impact of lower interest rates, the lower transactional volume, et cetera are – is clear in that. I think our view is that, if these conditions continue to prevail, then we think probably gross margins around these kinds of levels will also continue to prevail.

Obviously we do try to – we are continuing to try to effort – driving higher gross margins through active measures that we take, in terms of more cross-selling, et cetera, higher margin product. But I think that if these kinds of headwinds continue, I think these are probably – these are the probably the kind of levels that we would continue to see.

With regard to the RWA, it's actually – it is a good question. Obviously, and again as you say, apart from the second quarter performance and looking at it on more of a longer term basis, we continue to think the fixed income business is actually a – has been a relatively strong performer. I think, as David mentioned, the kind of first quarter to second quarter compare obviously makes it, it's – we are obviously disappointed with that compare on a quarter-to-quarter basis. On the other hand, if you look at first half of this year versus first half of last year, it's down I think about 6% in revenue terms, so it's actually held up reasonably well. And from a return point of view as well, for the first half of this year, our fixed income businesses had a pre-tax return of 17%.

And so that's – obviously we'd like to see that better, we hope we'll see better market conditions and we hope we can do a better job within managing the business but overall, that's actually – that's actually, I think, given what we've seen in market conditions in the first half, pretty reasonable return.

The question of how we get, as you say, to a flat RWA over that period and what the revenue outlook is? I think our general view is that in fact we can reallocate, we can adjust our business model, reallocate RWA within that, and continue to make good returns in that business. And we've talked about some of our investments for – we have – obviously, the main engines at this point are our credit business, particularly leverages finance and our structured products business, those have been the main engines. By the way, they – those were some of the businesses most affected in the second quarter, but those will continue to be, we believe, good businesses where we have very strong market shares and show good returns.

Our emerging markets business, as well, is a very strong business and that's one that performed well in the second quarter. Clearly, as you know, we are continuing to built out on our rates in our commodities businesses and we think that those will be businesses which are generally a little bit more risk-weighted asset efficient and actually can therefore produce, probably, more returns based on probably a lower level of RWA, but – Eric, I don't know if you want to add to that?

Sure. I think what I would add to that is, if you look at our stronger businesses and you look at the first half returns at a 17% return on pre-tax income over equity, it's an attractive business. We think the first quarter doesn't necessarily represent the type of business and the type of returns that we can put out to investors and to our shareholders. If you look at the two quarters – let me see if I can give you a deeper analysis of it and what actually happened.

In the first quarter, we generated CHF2.7 billion in top line revenues in FICC. In the second quarter, we generated CHF900 million of top line revenues, excluding OIS charges. Of that, client revenues were CHF2.2 billion in the first quarter and they were CHF1.6 billion in the second quarter, so the client revenues were actually quite strong across the two quarters, in fact, we actually took share.

When you look at the inventory, the inventory securities held for client trading in the trading, in the first quarter we gained $600 million. In the second quarter, we lost $900 million. We didn't do a terrific job with our inventory management on the securities in the second quarter, and we got caught in very difficult markets in illiquid situations, and we wanted to bring the risk down. So that caused the losses.

But the trading activity and the fundamental build in the sales effort in rates, FX, commodities, credit, has gone very well, and we're seeing real evidence of that. What's – we're also seeing is empirical evidence of that from third party agencies like Greenwich Research, that is coming back and saying, your penetration rates with key accounts is much better than it's ever been, but your cross-sale is much better than it's ever been. So the outlook for fixed income, if you look at the first half of the year and the 17% pre-tax return on equity, is quite good. The power of structured products, the credit business, the emerging market biz, we think will continue and we think there's real upside for us in some of these sales flows, as we can monetize better, through the trading effort, that P&L, so we're actually pretty optimistic.

In terms of mitigation, we have moved into Basel 2 and prepared through the Basel 2.5. So we are one those banks that has been a leader in mitigating capital and repositioning our business, and we feel like we can continue to do that into a B3 world, so we do have some experience with that, and have done that.
Walter?

So the underlying strength, roughly about CHF200 million year-over-year, is about – a third is coming from net new assets, obviously, which we generated over the years now, they come to fruition. Then about a third is repricing of services across various aspects of our business, and obviously another third is real estate.
Other questions here? Yeah. I guess you have – okay. First we'll go to (36:40) to you next. Go ahead. No, go ahead.

Two brief questions for you, if I may. You've given some detail on sensitivity on FX and on interest rates; that's helpful, thanks very much. What about client activity, which you mentioned is the third decisive factor for potential upside going forward? Can you give us some sort of sensitivity feel there? And – I'll let you answer this one first. Then I have a brief second one.
You can go ahead.

Okay. The second one... hello? Yeah. the second one would be, post the restructuring exercise, where do you think your cost-income ratio in the IB is going to end up? If I had a look at it correctly when I was standing in – 91% and over the longer term ,where would you like it to be?

Okay, good. Thank you. Actually on the first point, it's interesting. We debated. I was actually in favor of including some estimates of, as you say, looking at previous periods with higher client activity and what the impact of that would be. I don't know that we have a particularly specific answer for that because, as you say, if you – it depends on what environment you want to assume, if you go back to more active periods or even if you looked at the first quarter and all the client activity and kind of put it onto the business model, I think we still believe that, overall, you could take in the private bank, obviously if you take the transaction margin that's obviously been quite depressed, particularly in the second quarter, if you looked at that on a more normalized basis, our hope would be that eventually we could get back to some of the more historically high levels there, how quickly that will happen or whether we'll get completely back to that level, it's a question. I don't know, Walter, if you want to address that quickly?
When you look at it normalized, before the crisis, it was probably 250 higher, after the crisis 150, so that's sort of like some guiding points.

But I think also, if you look on the investment banking side as well, obviously additional flow, additional activity could be helpful there. Although we do see – we still have strong backlogs and obviously, even in the second quarter, if you look at our advisory business and our equity business, and the primary business in general, there was a fair amount of flow, obviously in the current market conditions, that's slowed down in terms of execution, but if markets get back to normal ,you could see some significant improvement there.

To the cost-income point, I think I will answer that at the group level; you can see that the cost-income ratio was 82.6% in the second quarter, 79.3% in the first quarter. And I think the point about the cost reduction program is that we're talking about CHF1 billion net cost reductions. So one can simply take it off. And the answer is, one would expect the cost-income ratio to drop by about 4%, everything else being equal, from CHF250 million of those cost savings on a like-on-like basis.

We've not given, as yet, the breakdown cost ratio – the cost benefits across the three divisions, I would say the majority of the benefits are expect to be the investment bank, but I don't think I'd want to be as precise as yet as saying what that would mean for the cost-income ratio, but everything else being equal, it is not – is a net cost reduction program, so you would reduce the group one by 4%, as from these numbers.
And over the longer term, for the IB cost-income ratio, where do you think it should be?
Well, I think we've – I think that's – we've laid out actually as one of our KPIs, I think. Where what was it set at? I think it's -
I think it's set at 25%.

And I don't think that – I think actually the Basel, the Basel announcement, some of the other announces that we've seen have, as you say, backed away from contingent capital as a way to satisfy the core capital requirement, but I don't think they've actually closed the door on those being capital instruments that can be used to supplement capital overall.
